Ops.Name: err
Ops.Doc: Fail immediately.

Ops.Name: sha256
Ops.Doc: SHA256 hash of value A, yields [32]byte

Ops.Name: keccak256
Ops.Doc: Keccak256 hash of value A, yields [32]byte

Ops.Name: sha512_256
Ops.Doc: SHA512_256 hash of value A, yields [32]byte

Ops.Name: ed25519verify
Ops.Doc: for (data A, signature B, pubkey C) verify the signature of ("ProgData" || program_hash || data) against the pubkey => {0 or 1}
Ops.DocExtra: The 32 byte public key is the last element on the stack, preceded by the 64 byte signature at the second-to-last element on the stack, preceded by the data which was signed at the third-to-last element on the stack.

Ops.Doc: A plus B. Fail on overflow.
Ops.DocExtra: Overflow is an error condition which halts execution and fails the transaction. Full precision is available from `addw`.

Ops.Doc: A minus B. Fail if B > A.
A divided by B (truncated division). Fail if B == 0.
Ops.DocExtra: `divmodw` is available to divide the two-element values produced by `mulw` and `addw`.

Ops.Doc: A times B. Fail on overflow.
Ops.DocExtra: Overflow is an error condition which halts execution and fails the transaction. Full precision is available from `mulw`.

Ops.Name: <
Ops.Doc: A less than B => {0 or 1}

Ops.Name: >
Ops.Doc: A greater than B => {0 or 1}

Ops.Name: <=
Ops.Doc: A less than or equal to B => {0 or 1}

Ops.Name: >=
Ops.Doc: A greater than or equal to B => {0 or 1}

Ops.Name: &&
Ops.Doc: A is not zero and B is not zero => {0 or 1}
A is not zero or B is not zero => {0 or 1}
A is equal to B => {0 or 1}
A is not equal to B => {0 or 1}
A == 0 yields 1; else 0

Ops.Name: len
Ops.Doc: yields length of byte value A

Ops.Name: itob
Ops.Doc: converts uint64 A to big-endian byte array, always of length 8

Ops.Name: btoi
Ops.Doc: converts big-endian byte array A to uint64. Fails if len(A) > 8. Padded by leading 0s if len(A) < 8.
Ops.DocExtra: `btoi` fails if the input is longer than 8 bytes.

Ops.Doc: A modulo B. Fail if B == 0.
A bitwise-or B

Ops.Name: &
Ops.Doc: A bitwise-and B
A bitwise-xor B
bitwise invert value A

Ops.Name: mulw
Ops.Doc: A times B as a 128-bit result in two uint64s. X is the high 64 bits, Y is the low

Ops.Name: addw
Ops.Doc: A plus B as a 128-bit result. X is the carry-bit, Y is the low-order 64 bits.

Ops.Name: divmodw
Ops.Doc: W,X = (A,B / C,D); Y,Z = (A,B modulo C,D)
Ops.DocExtra: The notation J,K indicates that two uint64 values J and K are interpreted as a uint128 value, with J as the high uint64 and K the low.

Ops.Name: intcblock
Ops.Doc: prepare block of uint64 constants for use by intc
Ops.DocExtra: `intcblock` loads following program bytes into an array of integer constants in the evaluator. These integer constants can be referred to by `intc` and `intc_*` which will push the value onto the stack. Subsequent calls to `intcblock` reset and replace the integer constants available to the script.

ImmediateNote.Comment: a block of int constant values
ImmediateNote.Name: UINT ...

Ops.Name: intc
Ops.Doc: Ith constant from intcblock

Ops.Name: intc_0
Ops.Doc: constant 0 from intcblock

Ops.Name: intc_1
Ops.Doc: constant 1 from intcblock

Ops.Name: intc_2
Ops.Doc: constant 2 from intcblock

Ops.Name: intc_3
Ops.Doc: constant 3 from intcblock

Ops.Name: bytecblock
Ops.Doc: prepare block of byte-array constants for use by bytec
Ops.DocExtra: `bytecblock` loads the following program bytes into an array of byte-array constants in the evaluator. These constants can be referred to by `bytec` and `bytec_*` which will push the value onto the stack. Subsequent calls to `bytecblock` reset and replace the bytes constants available to the script.

ImmediateNote.Comment: a block of byte constant values
ImmediateNote.Name: BYTES ...

Ops.Name: bytec
Ops.Doc: Ith constant from bytecblock

Ops.Name: bytec_0
Ops.Doc: constant 0 from bytecblock

Ops.Name: bytec_1
Ops.Doc: constant 1 from bytecblock

Ops.Name: bytec_2
Ops.Doc: constant 2 from bytecblock

Ops.Name: bytec_3
Ops.Doc: constant 3 from bytecblock

Ops.Name: arg
Ops.Doc: Nth LogicSig argument

Ops.Name: arg_0
Ops.Doc: LogicSig argument 0

Ops.Name: arg_1
Ops.Doc: LogicSig argument 1

Ops.Name: arg_2
Ops.Doc: LogicSig argument 2

Ops.Name: arg_3
Ops.Doc: LogicSig argument 3

Ops.Name: txn
Ops.Doc: field F of current transaction

Ops.Name: global
Ops.Doc: global field F

Ops.Name: gtxn
Ops.Doc: field F of the Tth transaction in the current group
Ops.DocExtra: for notes on transaction fields available, see `txn`. If this transaction is _i_ in the group, `gtxn i field` is equivalent to `txn field`.

Ops.Name: load
Ops.Doc: Ith scratch space value. All scratch spaces are 0 at program start.

ImmediateNote.Comment: position in scratch space to load from
ImmediateNote.Name: I

Ops.Name: store
Ops.Doc: store A to the Ith scratch space

ImmediateNote.Comment: position in scratch space to store to
ImmediateNote.Name: I

Ops.Name: txna
Ops.Doc:
Ith value of the array field F of the current transaction
`txna` can be called using `txn` with 2 immediates.

Ops.Name: gtxna
Ops.Doc:
Ith value of the array field F from the Tth transaction in the current group
`gtxna` can be called using `gtxn` with 3 immediates.

Ops.Name: gtxns
Ops.Doc: field F of the Ath transaction in the current group
Ops.DocExtra: for notes on transaction fields available, see `txn`. If top of stack is _i_, `gtxns field` is equivalent to `gtxn _i_ field`. gtxns exists so that _i_ can be calculated, often based on the index of the current transaction.

Ops.Name: gtxnsa
Ops.Doc:
Ith value of the array field F from the Ath transaction in the current group
`gtxnsa` can be called using `gtxns` with 2 immediates.

Ops.Name: gload
Ops.Doc: Ith scratch space value of the Tth transaction in the current group
Ops.DocExtra: `gload` fails unless the requested transaction is an ApplicationCall and T < GroupIndex.

ImmediateNote.Comment: position in scratch space to load from
ImmediateNote.Name: I

Ops.Name: gloads
Ops.Doc: Ith scratch space value of the Ath transaction in the current group
Ops.DocExtra: `gloads` fails unless the requested transaction is an ApplicationCall and A < GroupIndex.

ImmediateNote.Comment: position in scratch space to load from
ImmediateNote.Name: I

Ops.Name: gaid
Ops.Doc: ID of the asset or application created in the Tth transaction of the current group
Ops.DocExtra: `gaid` fails unless the requested transaction created an asset or application and T < GroupIndex.

Ops.Name: gaids
Ops.Doc: ID of the asset or application created in the Ath transaction of the current group
Ops.DocExtra: `gaids` fails unless the requested transaction created an asset or application and A < GroupIndex.

Ops.Name: bnz
Ops.Doc: branch to TARGET if value A is not zero
Ops.DocExtra:
The `bnz` instruction opcode 0x40 is followed by two immediate data bytes which are a high byte first and low byte second which together form a 16 bit offset which the instruction may branch to. For a bnz instruction at `pc`, if the last element of the stack is not zero then branch to instruction at `pc + 3 + N`, else proceed to next instruction at `pc + 3`. Branch targets must be aligned instructions. (e.g. Branching to the second byte of a 2 byte op will be rejected.) Starting at v4, the offset is treated as a signed 16 bit integer allowing for backward branches and looping. In prior version (v1 to v3), branch offsets are limited to forward branches only, 0-0x7fff.

At v2 it became allowed to branch to the end of the program exactly after the last instruction: bnz to byte N (with 0-indexing) was illegal for a TEAL program with N bytes before v2, and is legal after it. This change eliminates the need for a last instruction of no-op as a branch target at the end. (Branching beyond the end--in other words, to a byte larger than N--is still illegal and will cause the program to fail.)

Ops.Name: bz
Ops.Doc: branch to TARGET if value A is zero
Ops.DocExtra: See `bnz` for details on how branches work. `bz` inverts the behavior of `bnz`.

Ops.Name: b
Ops.Doc: branch unconditionally to TARGET
Ops.DocExtra: See `bnz` for details on how branches work. `b` always jumps to the offset.

Ops.Name: return
Ops.Doc: use A as success value; end

Ops.Name: assert
Ops.Doc: immediately fail unless A is a non-zero number

Ops.Name: pop
Ops.Doc: discard A

Ops.Name: dup
Ops.Doc: duplicate A

Ops.Name: dup2
Ops.Doc: duplicate A and B

Ops.Name: dig
Ops.Doc: Nth value from the top of the stack. dig 0 is equivalent to dup

Ops.Name: swap
Ops.Doc: swaps A and B on stack

Ops.Name: select
Ops.Doc: selects one of two values based on top-of-stack: B if C != 0, else A

Ops.Name: concat
Ops.Doc: join A and B
Ops.DocExtra: `concat` fails if the result would be greater than 4096 bytes.

Ops.Name: substring
Ops.Doc: A range of bytes from A starting at S up to but not including E. If E < S, or either is larger than the array length, the program fails

Ops.Name: substring3
Ops.Doc: A range of bytes from A starting at B up to but not including C. If C < B, or either is larger than the array length, the program fails

Ops.Name: getbit
Ops.Doc: Bth bit of (byte-array or integer) A. If B is greater than or equal to the bit length of the value (8*byte length), the program fails
Ops.DocExtra: see explanation of bit ordering in setbit

Ops.Name: setbit
Ops.Doc: Copy of (byte-array or integer) A, with the Bth bit set to (0 or 1) C. If B is greater than or equal to the bit length of the value (8*byte length), the program fails
Ops.DocExtra: When A is a uint64, index 0 is the least significant bit. Setting bit 3 to 1 on the integer 0 yields 8, or 2^3. When A is a byte array, index 0 is the leftmost bit of the leftmost byte. Setting bits 0 through 11 to 1 in a 4-byte-array of 0s yields the byte array 0xfff00000. Setting bit 3 to 1 on the 1-byte-array 0x00 yields the byte array 0x10.

Ops.Name: getbyte
Ops.Doc: Bth byte of A, as an integer. If B is greater than or equal to the array length, the program fails

Ops.Name: setbyte
Ops.Doc: Copy of A with the Bth byte set to small integer (between 0..255) C. If B is greater than or equal to the array length, the program fails

Ops.Name: balance
Ops.Doc: balance for account A, in microalgos. The balance is observed after the effects of previous transactions in the group, and after the fee for the current transaction is deducted. Changes caused by inner transactions are observable immediately following `itxn_submit`
Ops.DocExtra: params: Txn.Accounts offset (or, since v4, an _available_ account address), _available_ application id (or, since v4, a Txn.ForeignApps offset). Return: value.

Ops.Name: app_opted_in
Ops.Doc: 1 if account A is opted in to application B, else 0
Ops.DocExtra: params: Txn.Accounts offset (or, since v4, an _available_ account address), _available_ application id (or, since v4, a Txn.ForeignApps offset). Return: 1 if opted in and 0 otherwise.

Ops.Name: app_local_get
Ops.Doc: local state of the key B in the current application in account A
Ops.DocExtra: params: Txn.Accounts offset (or, since v4, an _available_ account address), state key. Return: value. The value is zero (of type uint64) if the key does not exist.

Ops.Name: app_local_get_ex
Ops.Doc: X is the local state of application B, key C in account A. Y is 1 if key existed, else 0
Ops.DocExtra: params: Txn.Accounts offset (or, since v4, an _available_ account address), _available_ application id (or, since v4, a Txn.ForeignApps offset), state key. Return: did_exist flag (top of the stack, 1 if the application and key existed and 0 otherwise), value. The value is zero (of type uint64) if the key does not exist.

Ops.Name: app_global_get
Ops.Doc: global state of the key A in the current application
Ops.DocExtra: params: state key. Return: value. The value is zero (of type uint64) if the key does not exist.

Ops.Name: app_global_get_ex
Ops.Doc: X is the global state of application A, key B. Y is 1 if key existed, else 0
Ops.DocExtra: params: Txn.ForeignApps offset (or, since v4, an _available_ application id), state key. Return: did_exist flag (top of the stack, 1 if the application and key existed and 0 otherwise), value. The value is zero (of type uint64) if the key does not exist.

Ops.Name: app_local_put
Ops.Doc: write C to key B in account A's local state of the current application
Ops.DocExtra: params: Txn.Accounts offset (or, since v4, an _available_ account address), state key, value.

Ops.Name: app_global_put
Ops.Doc: write B to key A in the global state of the current application

Ops.Name: app_local_del
Ops.Doc: delete key B from account A's local state of the current application
Ops.DocExtra:
params: Txn.Accounts offset (or, since v4, an _available_ account address), state key.

Deleting a key which is already absent has no effect on the application local state. (In particular, it does _not_ cause the program to fail.)

Ops.Name: app_global_del
Ops.Doc: delete key A from the global state of the current application
Ops.DocExtra:
params: state key.

Deleting a key which is already absent has no effect on the application global state. (In particular, it does _not_ cause the program to fail.)

Ops.Name: asset_holding_get
Ops.Doc: X is field F from account A's holding of asset B. Y is 1 if A is opted into B, else 0
Ops.DocExtra: params: Txn.Accounts offset (or, since v4, an _available_ address), asset id (or, since v4, a Txn.ForeignAssets offset). Return: did_exist flag (1 if the asset existed and 0 otherwise), value.

Ops.Name: asset_params_get
Ops.Doc: X is field F from asset A. Y is 1 if A exists, else 0
Ops.DocExtra: params: Txn.ForeignAssets offset (or, since v4, an _available_ asset id. Return: did_exist flag (1 if the asset existed and 0 otherwise), value.

Ops.Name: min_balance
Ops.Doc: minimum required balance for account A, in microalgos. Required balance is affected by ASA, App, and Box usage. When creating or opting into an app, the minimum balance grows before the app code runs, therefore the increase is visible there. When deleting or closing out, the minimum balance decreases after the app executes. Changes caused by inner transactions or box usage are observable immediately following the opcode effecting the change.
Ops.DocExtra: params: Txn.Accounts offset (or, since v4, an _available_ account address), _available_ application id (or, since v4, a Txn.ForeignApps offset). Return: value.

Ops.Name: pushbytes
Ops.Doc: immediate BYTES
Ops.DocExtra: pushbytes args are not added to the bytecblock during assembly processes

Ops.Name: pushint
Ops.Doc: immediate UINT
Ops.DocExtra: pushint args are not added to the intcblock during assembly processes

Ops.Name: callsub
Ops.Doc: branch unconditionally to TARGET, saving the next instruction on the call stack
Ops.DocExtra: The call stack is separate from the data stack. Only `callsub`, `retsub`, and `proto` manipulate it.

Ops.Name: retsub
Ops.Doc: pop the top instruction from the call stack and branch to it
Ops.DocExtra: If the current frame was prepared by `proto A R`, `retsub` will remove the 'A' arguments from the stack, move the `R` return values down, and pop any stack locations above the relocated return values.

Ops.Name: shl
Ops.Doc: A times 2^B, modulo 2^64

Ops.Name: shr
Ops.Doc: A divided by 2^B

Ops.Name: sqrt
Ops.Doc: The largest integer I such that I^2 <= A

Ops.Name: bitlen
Ops.Doc: The highest set bit in A. If A is a byte-array, it is interpreted as a big-endian unsigned integer. bitlen of 0 is 0, bitlen of 8 is 4
Ops.DocExtra: bitlen interprets arrays as big-endian integers, unlike setbit/getbit

Ops.Name: exp
Ops.Doc: A raised to the Bth power. Fail if A == B == 0 and on overflow

Ops.Name: expw
Ops.Doc: A raised to the Bth power as a 128-bit result in two uint64s. X is the high 64 bits, Y is the low. Fail if A == B == 0 or if the results exceeds 2^128-1

Ops.Name: b+
Ops.Doc: A plus B. A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers

Ops.Name: b-
Ops.Doc: A minus B. A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers. Fail on underflow.

Ops.Name: b/
Ops.Doc: A divided by B (truncated division). A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers. Fail if B is zero.

Ops.Name: b*
Ops.Doc: A times B. A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers.

Ops.Name: b<
Ops.Doc: 1 if A is less than B, else 0. A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers

Ops.Name: b>
Ops.Doc: 1 if A is greater than B, else 0. A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers

Ops.Name: b<=
Ops.Doc: 1 if A is less than or equal to B, else 0. A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers

Ops.Name: b>=
Ops.Doc: 1 if A is greater than or equal to B, else 0. A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers

Ops.Name: b==
Ops.Doc: 1 if A is equal to B, else 0. A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers

Ops.Name: b!=
Ops.Doc: 0 if A is equal to B, else 1. A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers

Ops.Name: b%
Ops.Doc: A modulo B. A and B are interpreted as big-endian unsigned integers. Fail if B is zero.

Ops.Name: b|
Ops.Doc: A bitwise-or B. A and B are zero-left extended to the greater of their lengths

Ops.Name: b&
Ops.Doc: A bitwise-and B. A and B are zero-left extended to the greater of their lengths

Ops.Name: b^
Ops.Doc: A bitwise-xor B. A and B are zero-left extended to the greater of their lengths

Ops.Name: b~
Ops.Doc: A with all bits inverted

Ops.Name: bzero
Ops.Doc: zero filled byte-array of length A
